data.title: Create command for find in selection and add default keybinding
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Insiders
- OS Version: Windows 10

actions.find and editor.action.startFindReplaceAction no longer find in selection without having to click an extra button (#8787). The Find in Selection button doesn't have a keyboard shortcut.

I frequently replace in selections. Ideally:
- Select text
- Hit a keyboard shortcut bound to a new command
- The Find in Selection button is already enabled

Also, it would be nice if all buttons and fields in the find dialog could be bound to keyboard shortcuts.

data.title: Ensure settings files are owned by process.env.USER and not root when running under sudo
data.body: A follow up for #3884, when running `sudo code` _before_ `code` is run, the common settings files/folders need to be owned by `process.env.USER` and not `root`.

data.title: Give API to theme things OUTSIDE the editor frame
data.body: Including: sidebar, status bar, etc.

data.title: When selected text is replaced by tab, option editor.insertSpaces is not respected

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open any text file
2. Have option editor.insertSpaces set to true
3. Select a portion of text (size selected doesn't matter)
4. Hit Tab to replace selected text with a tab

Expected: selected text is replaced with spaces equivalent to a tab
Actual: selected text is replaced with actual tab character

data.title: Rename and format document is really slow
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.2.1
- OS Version: Microsoft Windows [Version 6.1.7601]

Slowness is new to this version. No extensions installed. Using Typescript with tsconfig.json like this: 
{
    "compilerOptions": {
        "module": "amd",
        "target" : "es5",
        "noImplicitAny": false,
        "removeComments": true,
        "preserveConstEnums": true,
        "emitDecoratorMetadata": true,
        "sourceMap": true
    },
    "excludes": [
        "node_modules"
    ]
}

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Highlight a variable and press F2 -> Really slow
2. Highlight code and press Alt+Shift+F -> Really slow

data.title: Show errors returned from sourceRequest
data.body:
Today errors returned from the `sourceRequest` are only visible on the dev console.

For that reason the sourceRequest implementation of node-debug manufactures content that contains the error message and returns success. 

I've cleaned that up and now node-debug returns proper errors.

For the UI we have these option:
1. workbench error notification
2. manufacturing an editor content for the error and showing this in the editor
3. having a '404'-like error page instead misusing an editor for that.

Option 1 is too heavy because the user has to dismiss the notification.
Option 2 is what we have today but implemented on the 'correct' side.
Option 3 would be the best solution.

For now 2 is fine by me, but we should involve UX to design something for 3.

data.title: npm_modules/vscode/bin/install does not handle 404 properly
data.body:
when vscode.d.ts cannot be be found (see https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/8834) the result will be "404: Not Found"  but bin/install checks for "Not Found".

Meaning it will not detect a failure in download.

data.title: npm_modules/vscode/bin/install silently uses github_token causing 404 to be injected to vscode.d.ts
data.body:
when you as user have GITHUB_TOKEN with no push access to vscode defined it gets added in request header to fetch vscode.d.ts it will fail fetching.

the file will end up with something like:

```
404: Not Found

export = vscode;
```

as consequence github extensions don't build.

data.title: TypeError: Cannot read property 'results' of null
data.body:
Saw this in my selfhost console, not sure how I got there:

Steps to Reproduce:
- Open Search view
- Type a term and hit enter twice

You see following error

```
TypeError: Cannot read property 'results' of null
    at t.onSearchCompleted (searchModel.ts:427)
    at t.onSearchError (searchModel.ts:435)
    at searchModel.ts:419
    at Object.m [as _notify] (winjs.base.raw.js:1209)
    at Object.enter (winjs.base.raw.js:901)
    at _run (winjs.base.raw.js:1068)
    at _error (winjs.base.raw.js:1041)
    at searchService.ts:83
    at Object.m [as _notify] (winjs.base.raw.js:1209)
    at Object.enter (winjs.base.raw.js:901)
```

data.title: Feature request: ability to open url from the terminal
data.body: It would be great if it was possible to click to open urls, like most unix terminals do, especially because you cannot select/copy text in the terminal right now.

data.title: Make resource URI available from all editor inputs
data.body:
Some benefits:
- the `matches()` method could be implemented using the URI in the base class
- we would have a `hashcode()` for all editor inputs that we can use in places needed
- the stacks model and some other places can ditch the questionable use of `getUntitledOrFileResource`
- it opens the door to allow to open any editor by just using a URI (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/6644)

data.title: Replaced README image of product to reflect new UI
data.body: Shows new features: tabs, extension management.

data.title: Intellisense does not work on newly created JS files until VSCode is restarted.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: OS X El Capitan 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open VSCode
2. open new window
3. Create a new JS file
4. Create a few variables in that file ex: var name = "bob"; 
5. Use CMD-SHIFT-O (no symbols show up for me)
6. Try typing some commands such as console.log, notice that the regular autocomplete window does  
    not come up.
7. Quit VSCode
8. Reopen VSCode
9. Reopen previous file
10. Autocomplete now works, and symbols show up (intellisense works)

**This does not happen when creating a new file through the command line interface**

data.title: Fixes #7500: Only update CSS if needed
Allow to Ctrl+click in File > Open Recent to open in new window
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.3.0-insiders
- OS Version:Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Press Ctrl
2. Using the File menu, File > Open Recent and select a folder

The folder opens in the current VS Code instance. Using Ctrl along with Open Recent should open a new VS Code instance according to the June_2016.md release notes ("Open Recent in a new Window").

Note: that Command Palette File: Open Recent does create a new VS Code instance.

data.title: Add conditional ctrl+c/v to copy on integrated terminal similar to cmd
data.body:
From @bldesign in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/6451#issuecomment-230595940

> Maybe integrated terminal can present same feature as native Windows terminal, on Windows.
> 
> In the property options there are edition options with the ability to active <kbd>ctrl</kbd> shortcuts. It's just what we are talking about. It kills the process only if there is no selection. Cool no? _VS Code_ can do it.
> 
> Sorry my preview is in french, but yours certainly looks the same.
> ![terminalpropertiesoptions](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2221676/16598938/75102700-4300-11e6-8063-0c357febefcb.png)
> 
> With all options enabled. You can:
> 1. Copy paste <kbd>ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>c</kbd> / <kbd>v</kbd> even when a process is running (kills only if no selection)
> 2. Always paste <kbd>ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>v</kbd> (after process ended)
> 3. Select text with mouse
> 4. Select text with keyboard <kbd>shift</kbd> + <kbd>←</kbd> / <kbd>→</kbd>
> 
> You can copy, paste and select text only with keyboard on Windows. 
> (Both terminal, integrated and not are Microsoft **Windows [version 10.0.10586]**)
> 
> Can you expose these options to user preferences?

data.title: Cursor position changes when you cancel multicursor
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1, 1.3.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Select text
2. `editor.action.changeAll`
   - You can see, that cursor is now in position of the first multicursor element
3. Cancel multicursor
   - Cursor stays in position of the first multicursor element

data.title: Can't find module with extension .es6
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: Windows 8.1

Some projects I work on use `.es6` extension for JavaScript files that import/export using ES6 module syntax.

While webstorm and webpack seem to have no issues with this setup, VSCode gives a red squiggly saying `[js] Cannot find module './filename.es6'.`

Is there some way to get VS Code to find modules imported that do not have a `.js` extension? We would like to use `.jsx` in a similar fashion.

I have this for a .jsconfig:

```
    {
        "compilerOptions": {
            "target": "ES6",
            "module": "commonjs"
        },
        "files": [
            "**/*.jsx",
            "**/*.es6",
            "**/*.js"
        ]
    }
```

...and tried adding `.es6` under user settings for VSCode, but suspect I did it wrong or that doesn't solve the issue.

Also opened StackOverflow here:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38046039/vs-code-es6-extensions-cant-find-module
